Block Legend DX is an attempt of a game to strategize and plan your moves in an RPG match-3(match-2 actually) fashion. Games like 10,000,000 or You must build a boat but in a tactical and slower pace.

Compared to those 2 games where you need to be fast, In Block Legend DX, you must carefully maintain your board so you  have something to use or don't get stuck especially for the final boss. Another difference is this game is also a rouge-like, so when you die, you're going to start a new game. You grind for the star blocks which is the only currency in-game, it is used for everything like:

- Character unlock
- Dungeon/Place unlock
- Starting Item and consumable

What I don't really like is the third one, having to pay for the starting item and consumable. Not only you need to grind for unlocks, it makes the grind slower if you opted to bring a starting item/weapon.

I really like the idea in this game, also the difficulty is ok to me since you actually need to think rather than using your reflexes. You need to actually prioritize stats, and not do a jack of all trades build, but the progression kills it for me. Too grindy and that cost for the starting item/consumable is too much. Finally, the difficulty spikes: Unlike 10,000,000 and YMMB, those 2 games  have a nice difficulty spike, but this game, I can't even pass the third boss because once you there, you only have 2 turns to do ♥♥♥♥ while he does 20dmg+ to you.

For the PC port, I don't recommend this game. Meanwhile, I'm currently downloading this on my phone.

I’m going to put more (somewhat more) thought into this review than the developer put into porting this thing to PC.

Its a puzzle game. Find at least two matching tiles and stuff happens. But there is so much WRONG with this game, that I cannot enjoy all of its positives. If you want those, read one of the positive reviews. This game has tried my nerves long enough. These were all the negatives that just keep slapping me in the face. And I’ve TRIED to get passed them:

- Escalating costs to every unlock in the game. For example, unlocking a character would first cost you 9 star blocks. Then 12, the 35...it just seems to keep going up. This is made worse by the fact that...

- You only earn one star block per boss you best in battle. You can get others by completing quests, but depending on setup, this could be doomed to fail because most of them rely on sheer dumb luck if you complete them or not. Even then, the most I’ve gained from a quest thus far is 3 at a time. There is the enemies which test your nerves, but a little later.

- You know how it most, COMPETENT RPG’s you can have a weapon AND armor? This game makes you choose one or the other. You can only hold one equitable and one consumable item at a time.

- The enemies are also a pain in the ♥♥♥! Their scaling is awesome compared to how poorly you scale. The bosses scale EVEN HARDER (like they should), but the problem comes in when eventually, you will reach a point where you are unable to keep up and you WILL DIE. The fact that the previously mentioned one piece of gear at a time thing only makes the worse.

- There is no real feedback when you go to use items that destroy rows/columns. When it comes to consumables, you click on them, click the OK button and they go into play. When you use row/column destroying items you only see the cancel button. Nothing else changes to show that you’re in the midst of using the item, like the cursor could change, or the row/column could change color as you’re moving over the blocks.

- This last one is just a knit pick, but why are their tablet/smartphone terms like “swipe” in a game that is on the PC!?

I could go on. But this review is getting long, and if I go further, I will have officially put more work into this than the developer put in the port of this game.

Block Legend DX is a legend alright. A bad one. I’m usually one to give a smartphone game a shot on the PC, but this time my faith was misplaced. In short, the port is terrible and the developer should feel terrible.

reviewText:
This game is advertised as a puzzle/JRPG. Its an alright puzzle game but I’m not quite sure it fits any JRPG elements. Lets first start off with the puzzle aspect of this game. There’s very little skill involved between battles and the game constitutes of clicking on matching blocks to attack enemies, heal and defend. There’s only 6 block types: treasure chest, gold, attack, magic, defend and heal. When you aren’t fighting enemies attack blocks transform into experience until your next battle.

In essence the puzzle aspect of this game is more of a roguelike / time trial. In between facing foes you’re basically making a mad dash to match as many blocks as possible to level up. And the blocks you get are random with very little ways to influence them. There are a few items that might get rid of a certain block type or change one block into another but overall items are pretty random and not at all easily accessible as item costs are fixed and show up randomly. So you’re very likely to reach a store selling a high priced item when you just start out on your journey.

There is also equipment available for purchase but it’s awkwardly done in that you don’t get to equip your item right out the store. It goes into your inventory that can be accessed in your next playthrough. While we’re on the concept of price and purchases you are given random quests that you gain star blocks through. Star blocks are used to buy items, characters and stages at the start of the game. You can earn them mostly by doing side quests or defeating section bosses. Remember the various equipment I mentioned that you can purchase during your quest? Well when you start a new game you now have the option of… purchasing it AGAIN with star blocks. So technically purchasing equipment in the field unlocks it. You have to purchase it with star blocks every time you start a new game if you then want to equip it. And note that you can only have one item and equipment at a time.

I feel like these crippling in game cost mechanics are leftovers from the app side of this mobile to PC game. It’s not a freemium model but sort of acts like it. The game never asks you for real money but the way the in game economy works it’s definitely a lot harder and less enjoyable not being able to purchase stuff.

Now on to the RPG side. RPG to me has the impression that there’s going to be a story in there somewhere. You start the game and you just keep breaking blocks. You only see NCPs to buy stuff from them and that’s pretty much all the interaction you have with the residents. There’s no dialog to speak of, no characters to get to know. You do have HP, MP and gain experience but that’s the extent of any RPG elements present in the game.

I will say I enjoy playing this game for what it is and not what it’s pretending to be. It’s a grindy, casual tough as nails puzzle game where luck and speed play as big a role as any skill you might have for these types of games. It won’t appeal to RPG fans but if you want a bit of a time killer then this will suffice for a short casual playthrough when bored.

reviewText:
An interesting mix of rogue-like and puzzle game, you take a character on a quest fighting monsters and bosses and earning stars to unlock more stuff.  This is a great and well-thought out, simple game that is incredibly addictive.  This game is small and will run on just about anything.

And for all of those people who are complaining about how the game isn't engaging and all that other nonsense....it's a casual puzzle game.  It's not meant to be played for hours and hours on end (even though I sometimes do that as a distraction to other thigns).  It's a short and simple game, meant to be picked up, enjoyed, and put down before moving on to other things.  I don't really understand why this is such a hard thing for people to understand.

A few tips:  The DX doesn't only refer to this game as a port from some other console, new features were added to it. If you scroll down to the bottom of the character list, there are some extra characters down there.  If you are having a particularly hard time with things, try using Unity-chan.  She starts with a very high vitality stat, doesn't need to be unlocked with stars, and will probably give you a higher survivability.

Stars aren't meant to be something that you just get constantly to unlock stuff.  They aren't particularly hard to get, but you don't get them in large quantities.  This is done as a simple 'effort and reward' system.  If you spend the effort to unlock something, you will most likely enjoy how that changes gameplay for you.  It's not a part of microtransactions or other nonsense, it's just something to reward players who play the game long enough to unlock stuff.  Quests are easily cycled through in most cases, and if a quest is proving too hard to fulfill, you'll eventually come across an npc who can change it for 100 gold.

Lastly, items have a huge impact on the game.  You unlock things as you purchase them in the game for coins.  You can then start with those items for a guaranteed advantage on your next playthrough at the cost of stars.  If you are having trouble getting through something, don't be afraid to buy items and experiment with them so that you can use them later.
